title: John Lyon (boxer)
text:
John Patrick Lyon <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">MBE</a> (born 9 March 1962) is a retired <a href="boxing">boxer</a> from <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a>.
Boxing career.
A member of the Greenall St. Helens Amateur Boxing Club he competed at the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a> and <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>. He represented <a href="England%20at%20the%201982%20Commonwealth%20Games">England</a> and won a <a href="silver%20medal">silver medal</a> in the light flyweight division, at the <a href="1982%20Commonwealth%20Games">1982 Commonwealth Games</a> in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>, <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. Four years later he represented <a href="England%20at%20the%201986%20Commonwealth%20Games">England</a> again and won a <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> in the men's flyweight division (– 48 kg), at the <a href="1986%20Commonwealth%20Games">1986 Commonwealth Games</a> in <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. He appeared at a third consecutive games in 1990.
Lyon won eight English <a href="England%20Boxing%20National%20Amateur%20Championships">ABA titles</a>, four flyweight and four light-flyweight and a bronze medal in the 1991 <a href="Acropolis%20Cup%20%28boxing%29">Acropolis Cup</a>, retiring immediately afterwards.
He was awarded an <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Most%20Excellent%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">MBE</a> for services to amateur boxing.

Personal life.
Lyon's son <a href="Craig%20Lyon">Craig Lyon</a> also won the English light-flyweight title, twice. He also competed in the Prizefighter tournament at super-flyweight in 2011, but was defeated by <a href="Ryan%20Farrag">Ryan Farrag</a> in the quarter finals.
